abstracts.cdata!:
This project paper provides additional
            financing to the Federal Republic of Nigeria, Second Health
            Systems Development Project (HSDP II). The Bank has been
            supporting the thirty-six states of the Nigerian Federation
            through the HSDP II in improving the maternal and child
            health (MCH) status in Nigeria, which is amongst the poorest
            in Sub Saharan Africa. The additional credit will help
            finance the costs that accrued after the project was
            restructured in 2005 and implementation was accelerated and
            effectively scaled up. Of the total proposed supplement is
            allocated to 22 States and the Federal Ministry of Health,
            that were selected based on their performance to date, and
            will support the completion of original project activities
            that had already been approved in work plans for the
            improved delivery of primary health care services. The 22
            states expected to participate in the first instance are:
            Akwa Ibom, Abia, Anambra, Bauchi, Benue, Borno, Ekiti,
            Enugu, Gombe, Imo, Jigawa, Kebbi, Kogi, Kano, Kwara,
            Nasarawa, Ondo, Osun, Plateau, Sokoto Taraba and the FCT.
            The additional credit will specifically support four sets of
            activities within the broader context of strengthening
            primary health care services, namely: (a) rehabilitation and
            refurbishment of schools of health technology and schools of
            nursing and midwifery, with the twin objectives of
            augmenting the numbers of qualified health care personnel
            and of having these schools secure relevant accreditation;
            (b) support services, including the refurbishment and
            equipping of primary health facilities at the community
            level, training of health service workers, procurement of
            drugs and other medical supplies; (c) immunization
            activities, such as the procurement and repair of the cold
            chain equipment and training of vaccinators; and (d)
            strengthening of monitoring and evaluation (M&E) systems
            and processes at both the State and Federal levels.
